text: My client has their domain hosted on Wordpress, they just bought CMS Hub Pro and want to build one website page on HubSpot while leaving the rest of thier site pages on Wordpress (for now). Any ideas for how I can build one website page on HubSpot CMS while leaving the rest of the pages hosted on their current server, so that when a visitor visits this one page, it loads the HubSpot page at the same domain as the rest of the site?
Not going to be possible using Website Pages, but Landing Pages sounds like a good candidate for this use-case

Hey guys, thought I'd chuck this question in to see if anyone here knew of any tools that could help

I need to check to see if the HS tracking code is firing on all pages through different browsers. Seems on some sessions pages are not being picked up, where other sessions those same pages do get picked up. I wonder if safari's anti-tracking tech update (mar20) is to blame...
are you using the cookie notification?
a no could do that too.
but your right.. it totally could be. A few years ago a very popular tracking blocker was blocking HubSpot CTAS and forms.
wont the browser tell you what it blocked?
check this screen shot.
looks like it is being blocked
and it doesnt matter if they are coming from first part domains or thrid party either
<@U7SL518D6> <@U2H3TT8F2> just to bring this convo to your attention

Good point, not HS's cookie notification setup but there is one setup through the site (drupal cms).

Ran a quick comparison between google and hs sessions,. Looks like there is little consistency to define HS as the problem, seeing as google is lower in some instances.
Looks like I need to be checking google is running across all pages too!
that is close enough to consider it consistant
Probably should have run a bigger gap than the weekend to be fair..
there are often differences in tracking between the two
I'd have thought since both ga and HubSpotutk are both analytics they'd be way closer
nope

Just spotted a session with pages missing between 2 points, these missing pages definitely have the tracking code so it's a bit of a head scratcher. Will have to chuck it over to my web devs to see what they might find
Thanks for letting me run it by you though :+1:

Hey <@UP452DA2Z> we looked into this on our end.

From our findings, Safari isn’t actually blocking HS’ tracking script by default. Instead, you nailed it, Safari has implemented (<https://webkit.org/blog/8613/intelligent-tracking-prevention-2-1/|per this post>) a capability that limits the tracking to 7 days for first party cookies set through the document.cookie function.

What this means is that after 7 days a returning visitor will show up as a new visitor instead of being seen as a returning visitor.

You can verify that the tracking code is actually firing on your site by the presence of network requests to `<https://track.HubSpot.com/__ptq.gif>`
Hey guys, Can we show old blog post after update without change publishing date on top
